field_edited_text.value:
BATLWAYS AND UANALS

23



RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

———0-0 @ 00——

N 1784 a company was formed for the purpose of
constructing a canal from the Pennsylvania line,
along the Susquehanna to tide-water, and incor-
porated under the name of ¢ The Proprietors of
the Susquehanna Canal.”

To render the Potomac River navigable, ¢ The
Potomaec Company ” was formed in the same year,
and General Washington was chosen its first presi-
dent. So deep was the interest which he took in
this great design, that he assisted in the survey of
the river in person. It was then supposed that the
Potomac could be rendered navigable by locks and
dams and short canals, and the works for this pur-
pose were very soon undertaken; but experience
proved the fallacy of the idea. When the Potomac
Company was subsequently merged in the Chesa-
peake and Ohio Canal Co., these works were
abandoned, and a more comprehensive plan adopted,
that a more speedy and reliable means of communi-
cation might be had with the rich iron mines and
inexhaustible supply of coal contained in the moun-
tains of Western Maryland.

At a convention of delegates, from different
counties in Maryland, Virginia, and Pennsylvania,
held in Washington, Nov. 6, 18238, it was resolved
to form a company to construct a canal from
Georgetown, D. C., by Cumberland, to the coal
banks on the eastern side of the Alleghanies, and
thence to the highest point of navigation on the
Ohio or Monongahela.

The Ohio and Chesapeake Canal Co. was incor-
porated by act of the Legislature of Virginia, Jan.
27, 1824, and the charter was accepted by the stock-
holders, and the company formally organized in
June, 1828, and the work of construction com-
menced the same year. The canal was completed
in 1845, and is for the greater part from sixty to
seventy feet wide and six feet deep. The rise in a
distance of one hundred and five miles, from
Geprgetown to Williamsport, is three hundred and
fifty-three feet, which is overcome by forty-four
locks, one hundred feet long, by fifteen feet wide.
There are in this distance one hundred and nine-
teen culverts and six aqueducts, all built in the
most substantial manner, of solid stone masonry.

Maryland, looking to the interests of its com-
mercial metropolis, claimed and obtained the right
of constructing, through any portion of the District
of Columbia, a lateral canal, to terminate at the
city of Baltimore, and further insisted upon the
power, and maintained the expediency of the gen-
eral Government’s fostering this great national work
and aiding in its completion.

Owing to doubts of the feasibility of constructing
the lateral canal, and the evident necessity of open-
ing a more direct and speedy means of communi-
cation, the people of Baltimore, at an early day,
determined upon the construction of a railroad to
the waters of the Ohio. In February, 1827, a public
meeting was called in the city, and a memorial pre-
ferred at once to the Legislature. It was asserted
that the route of the railroad was the only practicable
one, that it was shorter by one hundred and forty
miles than the proposed canal, and that it could be
opened at an expense less by seven millions of
dollars. In ten days after the application, a charter
was granted by the Legislature.

The Annaroris ANp Erx Ripge RarLroaD, ex-
tending from Annapolis to Annapolis Junction, —
a point on the Washington branch of the Baltimore
and Obhio Railroad, —was completed in the year
1840, its length being 22:51 miles. For the
promotion of this enterprise, the State subscribed
the sum of $300,000 in bonds, of which $219,378
were issued. As a paying investment, this road
has not been a success, as it has probably never
earned more than would cover its operating ex-
penses,



The BaLriMore AND DruM Poixt RAILROAD, now
in course of construction, is to extend from Balti-
more in a southerly direction to Drum Point, in
Calvert County, a distance of about seventy miles.

The BarrimorE AND Onro Rarnroap CoMpANY was
incorporated in the State of Maryland, on the 28th
of February, 1827, with authority to construct a
railroad from Baltimore to some eligible point on
the Ohio River. With a capital of $5,000,000, and
the required subscription being raised, which was
one-fifth of that amount, the Company was organized
in the following April. After a satisfactory report
of the surveys, the construction was commenced,
and the ground broken at Baltimore on the 4th of
July, 1828. In a short time the first section of the
road, extending to Ellicott’s Mills, a distance of
fourteen miles, was put under contract, and com-
pleted in 1830. In this same year there was a sec-
tion of the road constructed within the city limits.

The year 1832 found the road extended to the
Point of Rocks, a distance of eight miles. In 1833
the work of construction was suspended, and no
additional mileage was added; but in the following
year it was again resumed, and the route extended
beyond the Point of Rocks, a distance of twelve
miles, to Harper’s Ferry.

In 1836 surveys were made for the extension of
the main road to Cumberland and Wheeling, for
which purpose $3,200,000 were subsequently sub-
scribed by the State.

At an early period in the history of the Company,
permission had been obtained from Virginia for the
location of the road through a portion of its terri-
tory. The time having elapsed in which the road
was to have been constructed, an act was passed,
1838, extending the time to five years, and requiring
the Company to locate within the State, with the
exception of five miles, —its road from Harper’s
Ferry to Cumberland. This act also designated the
city of Wheeling as the western terminus of thé
road. At the same time the State made a sub-
scription to the capital stock of the Company to the
amount of $1,058,420, being one-fifth of the esti-
mated cost of the road within its limits.

This act was accepted by the Company, and the
line to Cumberland, a distance of ninety - seven
miles, was placed under countract, and completed
in November, 1842,

No progress had been made in the construction
of the road beyond Cumberland from 1842 to 1847,
as the authority granted by the State of Virginia
had again expired. In 1847, an extension of time
was again obtained. In 1849, the means for re-
suming the work were provided, by the negotiation
of the bonds of the State granted to the Company.
From that date the work progressed rapidly, and in
1851 the road was extended from Cumberland to
Piedmont, a distance of twenty-eight miles; in
1852, from Piedmont to Fairmont, ninety-six miles;
and in the year 1853 the whole line of the road from
Baltimore to Wheeling, 1 distance of three hundred
and cighty miles, was opened to public use.

The BarriMore AND Poromac RATLROAD was char-
tered by the Maryland Legislature, May 6, 1853, to
extend from some point in or near the city of Bal-
timore, to a point on the Potomac River, to be
selected by the President and Directors of said
Company, not higher than Liverpool Point, and not
lower than St. Mary’s River, with such branches at
any point on said Railroad, not exceeding twenty
miles in length, as the said President and Directors
may determine.

The terminating points are Baltimore and Pope’s
Creek, on the Potomac River. The distance from
the Calvert Street Station, Baltimore, to Pope’s
Creek, is 74:20 miles.

Its Washington branch leaves the main stem at
Bowie, Prince George’s County, Md., 2552 miles
from Calvert Street Station, Baltimore, and ter-
minates near the capitol in Washington, a distance
of 17-08 miles.



Both cities are entered by tunnels; that in Balti-
more being nearly a mile and a half in length, and
costing over a million and a half of dollars.

Scarcely anything was done under the charter,
except a survey by Gen. Trimble, until late in 1860,
when its present president was elected a director,
and subsequently president. Ie at once addressed
himself with encrgy to the building of the road.

In the spring of 1861 contracts were made for
building the lower portion of the line to the An-
napolis and Elk Ridge Railroad, putting southern
Maryland in connection with Baltimore by rail, over
the Annapolis and Elk Ridge, and Washington
Branch of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad; but
the breaking out of the war precluded any work
being accomplished.

The war being over, the project was revived, and,
notwithstanding the violent and powerful opposition .
of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Co., the entire
line has been built, and is now in successful opera-
tion. It has been constructed of the very best
material, of the heaviest iron, and the largest oak-
ties, and its equipment is of the first character.

It was opened for travel between Baltimore and
Washington the second day of July, 1872, with six
passenger trains each way daily, and is doing a
good business from Lafayette, one of its suburban
Baltimore stations, to its depot in Washington.
The tunnel will be completed by April, 1873, when
trains will run, not only into the very centre of
Baltimore, but, through travel east and west, north
and south, will be transported through and under the
city by steam, without any delay or change of cars.

The CoLumpia aANp Port DEPostT RAILROAD is in
process of construction, and will extend, when
completed, along the left bank of the Susquehanna
River, from Port Deposit, Md., to Columbia, Pa., a
distance of 89,3 miles, 10 8 being in Maryland, and
28% in Pennsylvania.

About five miles of the main track have been
completed, forming a connection from the present
southern terminus of the Philadelphia and Balti-
more Central Railroad, at the mouth of the Octo-
rora Creek, and the Philadelphia, Wilmington, and
Baltimore Branch from Perrysville to Port Deposit,
and is operated by the P., W., & B. RR. Co. The
entire line, it is expected, will be open for traffic in
the fall of 1873, and, when completed, will form
another great outlet for coal, running direct to tide-
water, with all grades favorable for the loaded
trains.

The CuMBERLAND AND PENNSYLVANIA RAILROAD
was chartered on the 138th of March, 1850, and ex-
tends from Cumberland, Md., to Piedmont, W.
Va., a distance of thirty-four miles.

The lateral lines are Eckhart Branch, 14 miles;
Neff Run, Midlothian, Consolidation, and Furnace
branches, each 1} to 1} miles in length. Also,
Branch Line, 2} miles from Krugbaum’s (4 miles
from Cumberland) to Pennsylvania State line,
where it will join the Bedford and Bridgeport
Road, which in turn connects with the Huntingdon
and Broad Top Road, terminating at Huntingdon,
on the Pennsylvania Central Road.

The Cumberland and Pennsylvania Road was
built from Cumberland to Mt. Savage in 1844, to
Frostburg in 1852, and in 1857 to Lonaconing. In
1863 the George’s Creek Road, running from Lona-
coning to Piedmont, W. Va., was purchased, thus
completing the line throughout the centre of the
Cumberland coal-field, a distance of thirty-four
miles.

The CuMBERLAND VALLEY RAILROAD extends from
Hagerstown to Harrisburg, Pa., a distance of sev-
enty-four miles; only 575 of it lying within the
State of Maryland. This road was chartered on
the 2d of April, 1831. The work of construction
commenced in January, 1836, and the road was
completed from Chambersburg to the Susquehanna
River opposite Harrisburg, in December, 1887, a
distance of forty-nine miles.
